content: The Act may be cited as the "Lavender Offense Victim Exoneration Act of 2017" or the "LOVE Act of 2017". During the Lavender Scare in the 1950s and 1960s, over 1,000 Department of State employees were wrongfully dismissed for alleged homosexuality. The Department of State claimed their sexual orientation made them security risks. Many patriotic Americans were also barred from joining the Department. During the Lavender Scare in the 1950s and 1960s, over 1,000 Department of State employees were wrongfully dismissed for alleged homosexuality, deemed security risks. Many patriotic Americans were also barred from joining due to a screening process targeting individuals who appeared to be gay or lesbian, partly influenced by congressional investigations into federal employees' "sex perversion". Between 1950 and 1969, the Department of State had to report the number of homosexuals fired each year due to congressional pressure. The "Lavender Scare" led to over 1,000 wrongful dismissals of employees for alleged homosexuality. In the early 1990s, the Department of State's security office investigated State personnel suspected of being gay and expelled them as "security risks." Secretary of State Warren Christopher prohibited discrimination based on sexual orientation in 1994, and President Clinton signed an Executive Order in 1998 to prevent discrimination. In 1998, President Clinton signed Executive Order 13087 barring discrimination based on sexual orientation. In 2017, Secretary of State John Kerry apologized for past practices and reaffirmed commitment to diversity and inclusion for all employees, including the LGBTI community. SEC. 3. DIRECTOR GENERAL REVIEW. The Director General of the Foreign Service and Director of Human Resources, in consultation with the Historian of the Department of State, will review employee terminations since January 1, 1950, to identify wrongful terminations based on sexual orientation. A report compiling this information will be made publicly available within 270 days of the enactment of the Act, including historical statements from Department of State officials. The report will include historical statements from officials of the Department of State and Congress encouraging policies that led to the termination of employees based on their sexual orientation. The Secretary of State will review the consistency of Director General reviews under section 3 and submit reports to Congress within 270 days of the Act's enactment. Additionally, a Reconciliation Board will be established. The Secretary of State will establish an independent Reconciliation Board within the Office of Civil Rights to review reports on employees terminated during the "Lavender Scare". The Board will contact affected employees or their families to inform them of the inappropriate terminations. The Board will contact affected employees or their families to inform them of the inappropriate terminations. Additionally, a senior-level point of contact will be designated to receive testimony from employees or family members who experienced discrimination or termination due to sexual orientation. The Reconciliation Board within the Office of Civil Rights will review reports of discrimination and termination based on sexual orientation during the "Lavender Scare". Former employees can bring grievances to the Board if they believe they were terminated due to their sexual orientation. The Board will review each claim within 150 days and cannot dismiss claims due to lack of paperwork. The Department of State must provide information on each claim to prove no wrongful termination. The Board will terminate 5 years after the enactment of this Act. The Department of State must provide information on each claim to prove no wrongful termination. The Board will terminate 5 years after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF APOLOGY. Secretary of State Kerry apologized on January 9, 2017 for not providing equal protections to LGBTI officers and their families overseas. He emphasized his support for the LGBTI community and appointed a Special Envoy for the Human Rights of LGBTI Persons in 2015. In 2015, the first Special Envoy for the Human Rights of LGBTI Persons was appointed to promote LGBTI rights worldwide. The Department of State, like many others, discriminated based on sexual orientation in the past, leading to resignations and refusals to hire. Secretary of State Kerry apologized for these actions and reaffirmed the Department's commitment to equality. Congress offers a formal apology for its role in the "Lavender Scare" and similar discriminatory policies at the Department of State, which were influenced by congressional investigations into the sexual orientation of federal employees. The Department also apologizes for past practices and reaffirms its commitment to diversity and inclusion, including for the LGBTI community. Establishment of permanent exhibit on the Lavender Scare. The Secretary of State will collaborate with a public-private partnership to create a permanent exhibit on the "Lavender Scare" at the United States Diplomacy Center. The exhibit must be installed within one year of the Act's enactment and provide access to relevant reports. Material from oral sources will also be displayed. The exhibit on the "Lavender Scare" at the United States Diplomacy Center must display material gathered from oral testimony received from employees or family members of deceased employees who were subject to discriminatory policies. SEC. 8. GUIDANCE ON ISSUING VISAS. The Secretary of State must submit a report to Congress within 100 days of this Act, addressing countries denying visas to Foreign Service personnel's spouses based on sexual orientation. Recommendations may include ending visa reciprocity with such countries to ensure all spouses receive visas regardless of sexual orientation. SEC. 9. ESTABLISHMENT OF ADVANCEMENT BOARD. The Secretary of State will establish an Advancement Board within the Department of State to address issues faced by LGBTQI Foreign Service employees and their families. The Board will hear testimony from these individuals regarding discrimination based on sexual orientation and will issue reports annually for 5 years after collecting testimony. The Advancement Board within the Department of State will submit annual reports to Congress based on testimony from LGBTQI Foreign Service employees and their families regarding discrimination. The report will include recommendations to improve the Department of State and ensure no discrimination based on sexual orientation. The report will remain private and accessible only to Members of Congress, their staff, and the Advancement Board.
